node.name: Effect
node.description: How the stimulus effects the participants
Monetary values in some currency such as $10, or the ratio of the reward to the maximum possible (3 of max 10 becomes 0.3), or number Points
Absolute monetary values in some currency, for example $1, or the ratio of the reward to the maximum possible (3 of max 10 becomes 0.3), or number of Points

node.name: Planned
node.description: The error feedback was given regardless of the validity of subject response as in a yoked design

node.name: Warning
node.description: As in a warning message that you are getting too close to the shoulder in a driving task

node.name: Oddball
node.description: Unexpected or infrequent

node.name: One stimulus
node.description: Only oddballs are present but no frequent stimuli exist. See http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0167-8760(96)00030-X

node.name: Two stimuli
node.description: There are non-targets and targets. See http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0167-8760(96)00030-X

node.name: Three stimuli
node.description: There are regular non-targets and targets and infrequent non-targets, see http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0167-8760(96)00030-X

node.name: Target
node.description: Something the subject is looking for

node.name: Non-target
node.description: Make sure to tag Expected if the Non-target is frequent

node.name: Novel
node.description: Genuinely novel such as an event occurring once or so per experiment

node.name: Expected
node.description: Of low information value, for example frequent Non-targets in an RSVP paradigm

node.name: Valid
node.description: Something that is understood to be valid such as an ID matches the person being displayed and it has all the correct information

node.name: Invalid
node.description: Something that is understood to not be valid such as like an ID with an impossible date-of-birth, or a photo not matching the person presenting it

node.name: Congruent
node.description: Like in Stroop paradigm when blue colored text displays the word blue

node.name: Incongruent
node.description: Like in Stroop paradigm whena blue colored text reading displays the word red

node.name: Synchronous
node.description: When a mouse click sound happens right after clicking it

node.name: Asynchronous
node.description: When a mouse click sound happens with significant delay which give could the person a strange feeling. Or if in a movie the sound of the explosion is heard before it appears visually.

node.name: Correct
node.description: Confirm something went well and last action was correct

node.name: Incorrect
node.description: Confirm something went wrong and last action was incorrect

node.name: Non-informative
node.description: Feedback that provides no information in regards to correct, incorrect, etc.

node.name: Expected
node.description: Feedback was expected as in a positive feedback after a response that was expected to be correct.

node.name: Unexpected
node.description: Feedback was unexpected as when positive feedback was received when response was expected to be incorrect.

node.name: On accuracy
node.description: Feedback was provided by evaluating response accuracy

node.name: On reaction time
node.description: Feedback was provided by evaluating subject reaction time

node.name: To self
node.description: Default

node.name: To other
node.description: Observed feedback to another person such as in a social paradigm

node.name: Deterministic
node.description: Feedback has a fixed relationship to what happened before

node.name: Stochastic
node.description: Feedback is non-deterministic and does not have fixed relationship with what has happened before in the experiment

node.name: False feedback
node.description: Feedback that was not honest for example as in feedback of correct on an incorrect response or vice versa

node.name: Negative
node.description: Negative feedback was provided when it was not deserved

node.name: Positive
node.description: Positive feedback was provided when it was not deserved

node.name: Cue
node.description: An indicator of a future event, e.g. a sound cue that in 2-5 seconds a perturbation in driving will occur. Use (... Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Cue ~ hed tags for the event to follow, or main aspect of the event to follow) syntax.

node.name: Constant delay
node.description: The cue is for an event that will happen after a constant delay.
The delay, e.g. in seconds.

node.name: Variable delay
node.description: The cue is for an event that will happen after a variable delay.
The interval, e.g. between 2-5 seconds, of the variable delay.

node.name: Perturbation
node.description: Sudden movement or perturbation of the virtual environment in a car driving or other scenario

node.name: With SPGS
node.description: SPGS stands for spatial position guiding system

node.name: Without SPGS
node.description: SPGS stands for spatial position guiding system

node.name: Swab
node.description: Mouth swab

node.name: Shaking
node.description: being shaken or jerked around

node.name: Small
node.description: Pinkie or little finger
a number between 1 to 4, or 'REM'

node.name: Neutral
node.description: None of the above

node.name: Sense of community
node.description: Primed to have an emotion such as patriotism
SCI stands for Sense of Community Index
A number between 0 and 1
A number between 0 and 1
Default time is seconds

node.name: Competitive
node.description: Subject is competing against an opponent as for example when the faster respondent wins

node.name: Social interaction
node.description: Social

node.name: Pseudo
node.description: Instructed so but actually not as when the other person may not exist in real world such as the case of a computer program agent

node.name: Passive
node.description: There is a stimulus presentation but no behavioral measurements are collected from the subject. Subject is instructed not to make any behavioral outputs for example when told to carefully watch/listen/sense. The resting state is not considered passive.

node.name: Resting
node.description: State when there is no stimulus presentation and no behavioral outputs

node.name: Top-down
node.description: Instructed to pay attention to something explicitly

node.name: Bottom-up
node.description: something captures your attention, like a big bang or your name

node.name: Orienting
node.description: The lower state of the bottom-up or the pre-bottom up state

node.name: Covert
node.description: Implicit

node.name: Overt
node.description: Explicit

node.name: Selective
node.description: If you have two circles but asked to pay attention to only one of them

node.name: Divided
node.description: Attending to more than one object or location

node.name: Focused
node.description: Paying a lot of attention

node.name: Sustained
node.description: Paying attention for a continuous time

node.name: To a location
node.description: Spatial -- use the location attribute to specify to where the attention is directed

node.name: Alerting
node.description: Keeping the arousal up in order to respond quickly

node.name: Object
node.description: Visually discernable objects. This item excludes sounds that are Items but not objects

node.name: Personal
node.description: clothing that is on the body of the subject

node.name: 2D shape
node.description: Geometric shapes

node.name: Cross
node.description: By default a vertical-horizontal cross. For a rotated cross add Attribute/Object orientation/Rotated/ tag

node.name: Clock face
node.description: Used to study things like hemispheric neglect. The tag is related to the clock-drawing-test
Hour:min

node.name: Symbolic
node.description: Something that has a meaning, could be linguistic or not such as a stop signs.

node.name: Sign
node.description: Like the icon on a stop sign. This should not to be confused with the actual object itself.
Always give units e.g. mph or kph

node.name: Pseudo-character
node.description: Alphabet-like but not really

node.name: Letter
node.description: Authograph or valid letters and numbers such as A or 5

node.name: Drawing
node.description: Cartoon or sketch

node.name: IAPS
node.description: International Affective Picture System

node.name: IADS
node.description: International Affective Digital Sounds

node.name: SAM
node.description: The Self-Assessment Manikin

node.name: Action
node.description: May or may not be associated with a prior stimulus.

node.name: Involuntary
node.description: Like sneezing or tripping on something or hiccuping

node.name: Stumble
node.description: Temporary and involuntary loss of balance

node.name: Tether Jerk
node.description: When a tether attached to the subject is stuck/snagged and forces the participant to involuntary accommodate/react to it

node.name: Drop
node.description: For example something drops from subjectâ€™s hand

node.name: Open and close
node.description: Continue to open and close the fist, for example in motor imagery paradigms.

node.name: Open and close
node.description: Continue to curl and uncurl toes, for example in motor imagery paradigms.

node.name: Button hold
node.description: Press a button and keep it pressed

node.name: Eye saccade
node.description: Use Attribute/Peak for the middle of saccade and Attribute/Onset for the start of a saccade

node.name: Left base
node.description: The time of the first detectable eyelid movement on closing.

node.name: Left zero
node.description: The last time at which the EEG/EOG signal crosses zero during eyelid closing.

node.name: Left half height
node.description: The time at which the EEG/EOG signal reaches half maximum height during eyelid closing.

node.name: Max
node.description: The time at which the eyelid is the most closed.

node.name: Right half height
node.description: The time at which the EEG/EOG signal reaches half maximum height during eyelid opening.

node.name: Right zero
node.description: The first time at which the EEG/EOG signal crosses zero during eyelid opening.

node.name: Right base
node.description: The time of the last detectable eyelid movement on opening.

node.name: Eye close
node.description: Close eyes and keep closed for more than approximately 0.1 s

node.name: Keep
node.description: Keep the eye closed. If a value is provided it indicates the duration for this.
the duration (by default in seconds) that they keep their eye closed.

node.name: Eye open
node.description: Open eyes and keep open for more than approximately 0.1 s

node.name: Keep
node.description: Keep the eye open. If a value is provided it indicates the duration for this.
the duration (by default in seconds) that they keep their eye open.

node.name: With blinking
node.description: Default. Allow blinking during the eye-open period.

node.name: Without blinking
node.description: Without blinking during the eye-open period.

node.name: Turn
node.description: Change in direction of movement or orientation. This includes both turn during movement on a path and also rotations such as head turns

node.name: Tap
node.description: When there is nothing to be pressed for example like tapping a finger on a chair surface to follow a rhythm

node.name: Reach
node.description: Requires a goal such as reaching to touch a button or to grab something. Stretching your body does not count as reach.

node.name: Course correction
node.description: Change the direction of a reach in the middle to adjust for a moving target.

node.name: Stretch
node.description: Stretch your body such as when you wake up

node.name: Intramodal
node.description: In the same modality but with a change in details such as changing from paying attention to red dots and instead of blue dots

node.name: Intermodal
node.description: Between modalities such as changing from audio to visual

node.name: Stride
node.description: Use onset and offset attributes to indicate different walking stride stages

node.name: Faster
node.description: increasing the speed of walking

node.name: Slower
node.description: decreasing the speed of walking

node.name: Control vehicle
node.description: Controlling an object that you are aboard

node.name: Drive
node.description: Driving a vehicle such as a car

node.name: Correct
node.description: Correct for a perturbation

node.name: Stop
node.description: Brake a car

node.name: Pilot
node.description: Pilot a vehicle such as an airplane

node.name: Teleoperate
node.description: Control an object that you are not aboard

node.name: Allow
node.description: Allow access to something such as allowing a car to pass

node.name: Deny
node.description: Deny access to something such as preventing someone to pass

node.name: ID
node.description: Tag to identify any aspect of an event. Use parentheses to group an ID Value tag with an ID Type tag to qualify the kind of ID that the value represents.

node.name: Value
node.description: Use this tag by itself or in a parenthesized expression with an ID Type tag.

node.name: Type
node.description: Use this tag to define the type of ID in more detail.

node.name: Group
node.description: ID that identifies a group of events associated with each other.

node.name: Local
node.description: For IDs only defined in the scope of a single event. The local ID 5 in events 1 and 2 may refer to two different objects. The global IDs directly under ID tag refer to the same object through the whole experiment

node.name: Participant
node.description: ID identifies a subject.

node.name: Permutation
node.description: ID is used to identify an ordering as for example to indicate block order in an experimental design.

node.name: Reference object
node.description: ID is used to a reference object to specify location with respect to.

node.name: State
node.description: ID is used to identify a group of events that are changing the state of a variable as for example when the onset means the offset of any other and a change in the state

node.name: Synchronization
node.description: ID is used to tag an event for synchronizing data streams.

node.name: Direction
node.description: Coordinate system is inferred from Attribute/Location. To specify a vector combine subnodes with number --- for example Attribute/Top/10, Attribute/Direction/Left/5 to create a vector with coordinates 10 and 5

node.name: Top
node.description: Combine Attribute/Direction/Top and Attribute/Direction/Left to mean the upper left

node.name: Angle
node.description: Clockwise angle in degrees from vertical
Clockwise angle in degrees from vertical

node.name: Forward
node.description: Like a car moving forward

node.name: Backward
node.description: Like a car moving backward

node.name: Location
node.description: Spot or center of an area. Use Area were you are referring to something with significant extent and emphasizing its boundaries, like a city
location label

node.name: Lane
node.description: For example a car lane

node.name: Passing
node.description: The lane that cars use to take over other cars

node.name: xyz
node.description: have a subnode, e.g. Attribute/Location/Real-world coordinates/Room/xyz/10 50 30
Clockwise with units preferably in degrees
Distance is in meters by default
Preferably in degrees

node.name: Screen
node.description: Specify displacements from each subnode in pixels or degrees or meters. Specify units such as Attribute/Spatial/Location/Screen/Top/12 px
Clockwise angle in degrees from vertical
Displacement from screen center, in any direction, in degrees, cm, or other lengths
Displacement from screen center in any direction
Displacement from screen center in any direction

node.name: Top
node.description: You can combine Attribute/Location/Top and Attribute/Location/Left to designate UpperLeft and so on
Preferably in degrees

node.name: Object side
node.description: Could be the left, right, or both sides of a person or a vehicle

node.name: Bow
node.description: Front of a ship

node.name: Driver side
node.description: Side of a car

node.name: Passenger side
node.description: Side of a car

node.name: Stern
node.description: Back of the ship
In degrees or other units of angle
Default units are meters
In meters or other units of length
In cubic-meters or other units of volume
in meters

node.name: Duration
node.description: An offset that is implicit after duration time passed from the onset

node.name: Onset
node.description: Default

node.name: Repetition
node.description: When the same type of event such as a fixation on the exact same object happens multiple times and it might be necessary to distinguish the first look vs. others
Number starting from 1 where 1 indicates the first occurrence and 2 indicates the second occurrence

node.name: Response start delay
node.description: The time interval between this (stimulus) event and the start of the response event specified, usually by grouping with the event ID of the response start event.

node.name: Response end delay
node.description: The time interval between this (stimulus) event and the end of the response event specified, usually by grouping with the event ID of the response end event.
In Hz

node.name: Temporal uncertainty
node.description: Use to specify the amount of uncertainty in the timing of the event. Please notice that this is different from Attribute/Probability tag which relates to the occurrence of event and can be interpretative as the integral of probability density across a distribution whose shape (temporal extent) is specified by Attribute/Temporal uncertainty

node.name: Standard deviation
node.description: implies that the distribution of temporal uncertainty is Gaussian with the provided standard deviation (in seconds).

node.name: Imagined
node.description: This is used to identity that the (sub)event only happened in participant's imagination, e.g. imagined movements in motor imagery paradigms.

node.name: Condition
node.description: Specifies the value of an independent variable (number of letters, N, in an N-back task) or function of independent variables that is varied or controlled for in the experiment. This attribute is often specified at the task level and can be associated with specification of an experimental stimulus or an experiment context (e.g. 1-back, 2-back conditions in an N-back task, or changing the target type from faces to houses in a Rapid Serial Visual Presentation, or RSVP, task.)
the condition

node.name: Action judgment
node.description: External judgment (assumed to be ground truth, e.g. from an experiment control software or an annotator) about participant actions such as answering a question, failing to answer in time, etc.

node.name: Incorrect
node.description: Wrong choice but not time out

node.name: Indeterminate
node.description: It cannot be determined that the action was correct or incorrect.

node.name: Missed
node.description: Participant failed or could not have perceived the instruction due to their eyes being off-screen or a similar reason. Not easy to deduce this but it is possible

node.name: Inappropriate
node.description: A choice that is not allowed such as moving a chess piece to a location it should not go based on game rules

node.name: Social
node.description: Involving interactions among multiple agents such as humans or dogs or robots

node.name: Peak
node.description: Peak velocity or acceleration or jerk

node.name: Item count
node.description: Number of items for example when there are 3 cars and they are identified as a single item
Numeric value of number of items #
Number of items less than or equal to #
Number of items more than or equal to #
In HZ
in dB

node.name: Ramp up
node.description: Increasing in amplitude

node.name: Ramp down
node.description: Decreasing in amplitude

node.name: Time shut
node.description: The amount of time the eyelid remains closed (typically measured as 90% of the blink amplitude), in seconds.

node.name: Duration
node.description: Duration of blink, usually the half-height blink duration in seconds taken either from base or zero of EEG signal. For eye-trackers, usually denotes interval when pupil covered by eyelid.

node.name: PAVR
node.description: Amplitude-Velocity ratio, in centiseconds

node.name: NAVR
node.description: Negative Amplitude-Velocity ratio, in centiseconds

node.name: Up-down separated
node.description: Stimuli presented both at the top and the bottom of fovea
Angle of separation in degrees by default

node.name: Bilateral
node.description: For bilateral visual field stimulus presentations
Angle of separation in degrees by default
e.g. 3 degrees-per-second
e.g. 3 degrees-per-second
e.g. 3 degrees-per-second
e.g. 3 degrees-per-second
For example 4:30
In candelas by default

node.name: Aqua
node.description: These are CSS 3 basic color names
R value of RGB between 0 and 1
B value of RGB between 0 and 1
G value of RGB between 0 and 1
H value of HSV between 0 and 1
S value of HSV between 0 and 1
V value of HSV between 0 and 1

node.name: Achromatic
node.description: Indicates gray scale
White intensity between 0 and 1

node.name: Nonlinguistic
node.description: Something that conveys meaning without using words such as the iconic pictures of a man or a woman on the doors of restrooms. Another example is a deer crossing sign with just a picture of jumping deer.

node.name: Semantic
node.description: Like in priming or in congruence

node.name: Proper
node.description: A proper noun that refers to a unique entity such as London or Jupiter

node.name: Common
node.description: A noun that refers to a class of entities such as cities or planets or corporations such as a Dog or a Skyscraper
Actual word
Actual sentence
Actual paragraph

node.name: Story
node.description: Multiple paragraphs making a detailed account

node.name: Induced
node.description: Such as inducing emotions or keeping someone awake or in a coma with an external intervention

node.name: Arousal
node.description: Only in the context of 2D emotion representation
A value between -1 and 1

node.name: Positive valence
node.description: Valence by itself can be the name of an emotion such as sadness so this tag distinguishes the type of emotion
Ranges from 0 to 1
Ranges from 0 to 1

node.name: Supraliminal
node.description: By default this is assumed about each stimulus

node.name: Liminal
node.description: At the 75%-25% perception threshold

node.name: Probability
node.description: Use to specify the level of certainty about the occurrence of the event. Use either numerical values as the child node or 'low', 'high', etc.

node.name: Presentation
node.description: Attributes associated with visual, auditory, tactile, etc. presentation of an stimulus

node.name: Fraction
node.description: the fraction of presentation of an Oddball or Expected stimuli to the total number of same-class presentations, e.g. 10% of images in an RSVP being targets

node.name: Cued
node.description: what is presented is cued to the presentation of something else

node.name: Background
node.description: presented in the background such as background music, background image, etc. The main factor here is that background presentations are to be ignored, e.g. ignore math question auditory stimuli.

node.name: Intended effect
node.description: This tag is to be grouped with Participant/Effect/Cognitive to specify the intended cognitive effect (of the experimenter). This is to differentiate the resulting group with Participant/Effect which specifies the actual effect on the participant. For example, in an RSVP experiment if an image is intended to be perceived as a target, (Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Target, Attribute/Intended effect) group is added. If the image was perceived by the subject as a target (e.g. they pressed a button to indicate so), then the tag Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Target is also added: Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Target, (Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Target, Attribute/Intended effect). otherwise the Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Target tag is not included outside of the group.

node.name: Instruction
node.description: This tag is placed in events of type Event/Category/Experimental stimulus/Instruction, grouped with one or more Action/ tags to replace the detailed specification XXX in Event/Category/Experimental stimulus/Instruction/XXX) in previous versions. Usage example: Event/Category/Experimental stimulus/Instruction, (Action/Fixate, Attribute/Instruction)

node.name: Participant indication
node.description: This tag is placed in events of type Event/Category/Participant response and grouped with Participant/Effect/Cognitive/.. tags to specify the type of cognitive effect the participant has experienced. For example, in an RSVP paradigm, the subject can indicate the detection of a target with a button press. The HED string associated with this button press must include (Attribute/Participant indication, Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Target,...)

node.name: Velocity
node.description: Use Attribute/Onset or Attribute/Offset to specify onset or offset
Numeric value with default units of m-per-s
Numeric value with default units of m-per-s2
Numeric value with default units of m-per-s3

node.name: Constrained
node.description: For example a path cannot cross some region

node.name: File
node.description: File attributes
Numeric value with default units of mb
Number of files

node.name: Object control
node.description: Specifies control such as for a vehicle

node.name: Near miss
node.description: Almost having an accident resulting in negative consequences

node.name: Correct position
node.description: After a lane deviation or side of the walkway

node.name: Halt
node.description: Time at which speed becomes exactly zero

node.name: Cross
node.description: Crossing in front of another object such as a vehicle

node.name: Pass by
node.description: Passing by another object or the participant

node.name: Another person
node.description: Item such as a cup belonging to another person

node.name: Same person
node.description: Item such as a cup belonging to the participant

node.name: Extraneous
node.description: Button presses that are not meaningful for example due to intrinsic mechanical causes after a meaningful press

node.name: Role
node.description: The role of the agent (participant, character, AI..)
